Entry Types

Regular Entries

A regular jounral entry is one that is made to record a normal business transaction. Examples of regular journal entries include entries that record sales, record adjustments to inventory, and record expenses. Regular journal entries are immediatly reflected on all financial statements for the period they are recorded in.

Where are regular entries represented?
Current PeriodPrevious Period
On Income StatementYesYes
On Balance SheetYesYes
On Unadjusted Trial BalanceYesYes
On Adjusted Trial BalanceYesYes

Adjusting Entries

An adjusting journal entry is one made at the end of a period that records revenues/expenses from the current period that have not yet been recognized. Typically adjusting entries are cashless. Examples of adjusting entries include recording depreciation expense, adjusting prepaid expenses, and splitting up revenue/expenses such that they are allocated to multiple periods.

Where are adjusting entries represented?
Current PeriodPrevious Period
On Income StatementYesYes
On Balance SheetYesYes
On Unadjusted Trial BalanceNoYes
On Adjusted Trial BalanceYesYes

Closing Entries

A closing journal entry is one made at the end of a period that resets the balance of one or more temporary accounts. Closing entries transfer the balance of a temporary account to a permanent account such as retained earnings. Closing entries do not increase or decrease the amounts of assets, liabilities, or equity controlled by a company.

Where are closing entries represented?
Current PeriodPrevious Period
On Income StatementNoYes
On Balance SheetYesYes
On Unadjusted Trial BalanceNoYes
On Adjusted Trial BalanceNoYes
